articles.summary: Surrey County Council has issued safety advice for motorists and pedestrians to avoid walking or driving through flood water, which can cause injuries, and potentially lead to long waits for the water to clear. The Met Office has issued a storm warning covering a large area from Wales and the Midlands to the South East, which could lead to disruption and spray on roads. There are also potential torrential downpours, gusty winds, frequent lightning, and hail. The warning also covers a wide area, with warnings from Wales, the Midlands, and the East of England.

articles.title: You won't see a value meal at Shake Shack anytime soon — it doesn't need one
articles.description: Even amid the value wars, the chain reported a 16% sales jump in its last quarter
articles.content:
Shake Shack says its burgers and fries remain a hit among consumers – and a pricing shakeup isn’t coming soon.



The restaurant chain posted stronger-than-expected second-quarter earnings on Thursday... [2587 symbols]
articles.summary: Shake Shack, a New York-based restaurant chain, has stated that its burgers and fries are still a hit among consumers, despite the inflationary economy. The company posted stronger than expected second-quarter earnings, highlighting how diners are still buying fast food. CEO Robert Lynch argued that the chain's premium positioning is not a liability, but a strength. However, he emphasized the need for Shake Shack to broaden its consumer base, which currently includes high-income customers. Lynch did not anticipate a price cut, but emphasized the importance of improving service and value perception. The chain plans to open 40 new locations this year and is working to address its long-standing drive-thrus.

articles.title: Nearly half of insured Americans get surprise expenses in medical bills, study finds
articles.description: Most don't contest billing errors or denied coverage, even though doing so frequently works, the Commonwealth Fund says.
articles.content: Nearly half of insured Americans have been smacked by surprise medical expenses in the past year, but a majority don't contest billing errors or coverage denials, a new survey by the Commonwealth Fund... [1943 symbols]
articles.summary: A survey by the Commonwealth Fund has found that nearly half of insured Americans have received unexpected medical expenses in the past year, largely due to billing errors or coverage denials. The study, conducted by the nonprofit foundation, found that 75% of 7,873 insured adults reported being billed for a service they thought should have been covered, while nearly one in five reported being denied coverage for a doctor-recommended service. However, fewer than half of these individuals challenged the bills, mostly because they did not know they have the right to do so. The findings also revealed that more than a third of those who disputed medical bills had their balances reduced or eliminated, and half of those challenged coverage denial efforts succeeded in getting some or all denied services approved.

He also stated that he would have carried out the death penalty himself and said the agreement is a slap in the face for the families of the 2,657 American victims who have waited 23 years for justice. O'Negan, who served in 400 combat missions over 16 years, served in the most famous military raid in U.S. history that led to Bin Laden's death. He has publicly criticized the Biden administration for agreeing to the terms of the plea-deal and criticized the lawyers involved in the deal, stating they are detestable and weak. It is unclear where the terrorists will serve their sentences.

articles.title: Josh Shapiro Beat Trump In Court After 2020 Election—And Now Could Be On 2024 Ticket
articles.description: The Pennsylvania governor spent the last presidential election opposing Trump in court—and he soon could be against him on the ballot.
articles.content: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro is reportedly one of the top picks for Vice President Kamala Harris’ running mate in the presidential election—potentially putting him on the presidential ticket four ye... [4683 symbols]
articles.summary: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro is reportedly one of the top picks for Vice President Kamala Harris' running mate in the 2024 presidential election, potentially putting him on the presidential ticket. Prior to becoming governor, Shapiro served as attorney general in Pennsylvania and defended the state against former President Donald Trump in court. He successfully defended at least 19 lawsuits filed before the 2020 election and over 20 filed after Election Day. These include challenges to mail-in ballot rules by both the Trump campaign and GOP state candidates, including a major Trump campaign lawsuit by Rudy Giuliani. Many post-election challenges involving Pennsylvania were dismissed by the U.S. Supreme Court. Shapiro also gained attention for his work in investigating sexual abuse within the Catholic Church and his quick work in repairing a section of a highway in Philadelphia after a bridge collapsed.

articles.summary: Willie Nelson and Bob Dylan performed separately at the Hollywood Bowl as part of the Outlaw Music Festival. The sold-out show was part of a larger tour that features a third veteran of American roots music. This was the first time the two living legends had performed together since 2009. Nelson, who launched the annual Outlaw tour in 2016, opened his set with a rendition of "Whiskey River" and "Angel Flying Too Close to the Ground." Other notable performances included unannounced guests from John Densmore of the Doors, Amanda Shires, Lily Meola of "America's Got Talent" and Lily Meolas of "Will You Remember Mine" for a performance of "I'll Fly Away."

articles.title: Inflation & Stocks Heading Higher, Regardless of the Fed
articles.description: The U.S. economy and the stock market can thrive even if inflation doesn't fall to 2%.
articles.content: U.S. inflation news has been better lately and investors are anticipating that the U.S. Federal Reserve will cut interest rates soon. Whether that’s prudent — and what it could mean for stocks — hinge... [3946 symbols]
articles.summary: The U.S. Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose by 3% from the previous year, marking its best reading since March 2021. However, inflation remains above the Fed's 2% target and food and energy prices were up 2.2% and 1%, respectively, while other goods were down 1.8%. Non-energy services, which account for 61% of the CPI, are also experiencing inflation. Freddie Mac reports that the US has about 3.8 million fewer housing units than needed and wages are rising by 9.2%. An IMF study indicates that when a central bank eases monetary policies too soon, inflation reignites, another round of rate increases is required. Unemployment is now at 4.1%, up from 3.5% last July. If unemployment rises to 4.2%, the Sahm Indicator hits 0.5%, it will be Code Red. The inflation rate is not the best indicator of labor market tightness, but the supply of available workers.

articles.summary: Republican VP nominee, JD Vance, has taken his campaign rhetoric on immigration to the U.S.-Mexico border to further attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris' record, highlighting the Biden administration's approach to border security. Vance, a Republican senator from Ohio, visited an unfinished portion of the border wall in Arizona to emphasise the contrast between Harris and former President Donald Trump's records. He also highlighted the potential legal challenges posed by the proposed border policy, which includes mass deportation of undocumented immigrants if he is sent back to the White House. Following his visit, Vance continued his attacks on Harris, arguing that the courts have made it clear that the president has complete control over border policy and that the federal government has a lot of power over the issue. Harris defended her record on border security, citing her experience as California’s attorney general and her role in addressing the root causes of migration to the US from the Northern Triangle countries of Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras.

articles.summary: The Wall Street Journal fought for reporter Evan Gershkovich's freedom after an unsubstantiated report on Russian messaging service Telegram reported that security agents had removed a person from a restaurant in Yekaterinburg. The company, Dow Jones and the Journal, used social media and other media campaigns to secure Gerskkovich’s release. The allegations were later proven to be unfounded and false, leading to a flurry of public advocacy efforts. Dow Jones' CEO Almar Latour and the paper's editor in chief Emma Tucker reached out to high-level Biden administration officials and Secretary of State Antony Blinken promised support. articles.title: Iran, allies plan joint but limited retaliation against Israel
articles.description: Iran and armed groups backed by it are preparing coordinated action meant to deter Israel but avert all-out war, sources and analysts said, after the
articles.content:
Iran and armed groups backed by it are preparing coordinated action meant to deter Israel but avert all-out war, sources and analysts said, after the killings of top Hamas and Hezbollah figures.

On W... [4389 symbols]
articles.summary: Iran and its allies are planning joint but limited retaliation against Israel following the deaths of Hamas's leader and Hezbollah's top military commander, respectively. Iranian officials met with representatives from the "Axis of Resistance", a loose alliance of Tehran-backed groups hostile to Israel, to discuss possible responses. The potential responses could include a simultaneous response from Iran and allies or a staggered response from each party. Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has threatened a "harsh punishment" for the killing of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh, blaming Israel for the death. Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah warned his group was prepared to respond to Israel's killing of top commander Fuad Shukr. The Islamic Resistance of Iraq leader, leader of the alliance of pro-Iran groups, said Iran will lead the first response with the participation of Iraqi, Yemeni and Syrian factions, striking military targets, followed by a second response from Hezbollah.

The deal involved the release of convicted assassin Vadim Krasikov from a German prison, where he was serving life for the murder of a Chechen separatist.

articles.summary: The U.S. labor market may have cooled in July due to a gradual slowdown in the economy and Hurricane Beryl, which are expected to have reduced hiring. However, this decline is expected to be only incremental, consistent with the Federal Reserve's plan to engineer a gentle downshift. The Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics is predicted to show payroll gains of 185,000 on the month, down from 206,000 in June, with the unemployment rate holding at 4.1%. However, some economists believe the report could be on the light side due to Beryl's impact on payrolls. If the jobless rate continues to climb, it could trigger fears of triggering the Sahm Rule, which states that when a three-month period's unemployment rate exceeds its 12-month low, the economy is in recession.

articles.summary: New video footage reveals the moment Russia freed Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, former US Marine Paul Whelan, and others in a prisoner swap in Turkey. The exchange marked the most complex prisoner swap since the Cold War. The Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) released several videos of the prisoner exchange at an airport in Turkey, which were distributed by state-owned media agency RIA Novosti. The freed Americans are now on their way to the US. The deal involved at least six countries and followed months of high-stakes negotiations between the US, Russia, and Germany. The release of 16 people from Russia, including five Germans and seven Russian citizens who were political prisoners in their own country, was praised by President Joe Biden.

articles.summary: Vadim Konoshchenok, a suspected Russian spy, is being released as part of the prisoner swap that freed Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershovich and ex-U.S. Marine Paul Whelan. The prisoner exchange, which took place years in the making, freed 24 prisoners from seven nations and included a self-proclaimed "colonel" for Russia's intelligence agency, Konoshchensok. He was initially stopped at the Estonian border in 2022 with 35 types of semiconductors and other electronic components, as well as thousands of sniper rifle bullets. Koneshchenok was then arrested in Estonia a month later trying to cross into Russia with about 20 cases of bullets from the US. He has been held at Brooklyn’s Metropolitan Detention Center since July.

articles.title: Mpox outbreaks declared in Kenya and Central African Republic. The race is on to contain the spread.
articles.description: The outbreaks are in parts of Africa where vaccines and treatments are lacking.
articles.content:

Kenya and the Central African Republic have declared new outbreaks of mpox as Africa’s... [2383 symbols]
articles.summary: Kenya and the Central African Republic have declared new outbreaks of mpox, previously known as monkeypox, as Africa's health officials are trying to contain the spread of the disease in a region lacking vaccines. The outbreak was announced after a case was discovered in a passenger traveling from Uganda to Rwanda at a border crossing in southern Kenya. The Central African republic was the first to declare a new outbreak, extending to its capital of Bangui. The disease, which originates from wild animals and jumps to people, is caused by a virus that can spread it to others. The worst hit on Africa is Congo, which has recorded over 12,000 cases and at least 470 deaths this year in its biggest outbreak. The World Health Organization confirmed sexual transmission of mpx in Congo for the first time in November, which African scientists have warned could make it difficult to contain. The East African Community regional bloc has also issued a statement alerting member states about this disease in Congo, where it is most common in remote areas.

articles.title: Stocks nosedive as investors fret over signs of U.S. economic slowdown
articles.description: Stocks fell sharply after new economic data raised concerns the economy could be slowing faster than expected.
articles.content:
Stocks are tumbling after fresh economic signals raised concerns about the outlook for U.S. growth.

The Department of Labor on Thursday released data showing that initial claims for unemployment bene... [3110 symbols]
articles.summary: Stocks have dropped as investors worry about the outlook for the U.S. economy due to signs of a slowdown in growth. The Department of Labor reported that initial claims for unemployment benefits rose to 249,000 last week, surpassing analyst forecasts and reaching the highest level since August of 2023. New purchasing managers data also indicated that manufacturers are weakening due to higher interest rates, and companies reporting corporate earnings indicate softer consumer spending. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average have seen significant falls, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite also dropping nearly 3%. The Federal Reserve has been expected to lower its benchmark interest rate, but some fear it may be behind the curve in lowering borrowing costs, raising a hard economic landing. Despite this, data shows that the economy remains on solid ground.

During his playing career, Shakespeare played for clubs including Walsall, Sheffield Wednesday, West Brom, Grimsby, Leicester City, Hull City, Watford, Aston Villa and Norwich City. He was also Claudio Ranieri's assistant when Leicester won the Premier League title in 2016 and later succeeded him in the dugout at Leicester. Shakespeare also coached the Foxes to a famous victory over Sevilla to reach the Champions League quarter-final. Leicester striker Jamie Vardy led the tributes with a picture of the pair together. Everton Football Club also expressed their sadness over Shakespeare's passing.

articles.summary: Family members of U.S. citizen, Marc Fogel, have expressed disappointment in the Biden administration for not making him part of the biggest prisoner swap since the Cold War. The State Department confirmed that Russia was handed eight spies and agents, including political assassin Vadim Krasikov, who was convicted in Germany for a 2019 killing. In exchange, Putin freed 16 prisoners, including Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich and former Marine and computer security official Paul Whelan. In addition, Russia also released political prisoners Ilya Yashin, Vladimir Kara-Murza, Alsu Kurmasheva, Andrei Pivovarov, Oleg Orlov, Sasha Skochilenko, Lilia Chanysheva and business owner Vladislav Klyushin. The family was notified by the Biden Administration that Fogel would not be released.

This medal is a special one for the 21-year-old athlete, who has been told in 2023 that she may never compete in the sport again due to health issues. Despite these setbacks, Lee remains one of the three best gymnasts in the world and is now considered one of world's top three gymnasts.

articles.summary: Senate Republicans have blocked legislation that would have expanded the child tax credit, a key tax break for millions of families. Despite strong bipartisan support for the House bill passed in January, Senate Republicans resisted the legislation. The vote was held to show election-year positions by Senate Democrats. If implemented, the bill would have improved access to the credit and retroactively boosted the refundable portion for 2023. Approximately 16 million children would have benefited during the first year of the proposed expansion, according to an analysis from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. However, critics called the decision a "blatant attempt to score political points" by Senator Mike Crapo, R-Idaho.

The men remain in removal proceedings.

articles.title: What the presidential election could mean for Social Security and Medicare
articles.description: In the months running up to the November election, President Biden still has time to make his mark on Social Security and Medicare, expert says.
articles.content: When it comes to the November election, there is one issue that is at the top of voters' wish lists: Social Security. Despite political division, most Americans — 87% — want action to address Social S... [4734 symbols]
articles.summary: Despite political differences, 87% of Americans want action to address Social Security's trust fund shortfall, according to the National Institute on Retirement Security. The institute polled 1,208 individuals aged 25 and older and found that 69% of respondents believe a candidate's stance on Social Security will influence their vote in the presidential election. Experts are divided on how to address this shortfall, whether it should be through tax increases, benefit cuts or a combination of both. While the focus is on the presidential campaigns, President Joe Biden has a window of opportunity to address the issue. Some Democrats have proposed raising taxes for the wealthy and increasing benefits, while a bipartisan group of lawmakers have proposed forming a commission to identify next steps. While former President Donald Trump has suggested eliminating some Social Security taxes, experts believe this could increase the tax burden on seniors and individuals with disabilities.

articles.summary: The city of Naperville is asking a federal judge to dismiss a $20 million lawsuit by Amara Harris, a woman who was acquitted of a charge that she stole a classmate's AirPods while a student at Naperville North High School. Harris had filed a civil suit against the city and Naperville police officers Juan Leon and Jonathan Pope claiming their pursuit of the case caused her emotional and financial injury. The city has responded by stating that the lawsuit lacks any merit, nor is there a precedent for most of the claims Harris makes. The suit alleges that Harris was racially discriminated against and intimidated by the city due to the incident and claims that the police department has a history of improperly issuing tickets to students for minor infractions.

articles.summary: The largest post-Cold War prisoner swap between the U.S. and Russia was executed on Thursday, with the release of 16 people previously detained in Russia in exchange for eight held in the US, Germany, Norway, Slovenia and Poland. The prisoners were accused of crimes ranging from hacking to money laundering. Among them were Vadim Konoshchenok, a Russian-American journalist for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, and Vladimir Kara-Murza. Vladislav Klyushin was sentenced to nine years in prison for a "hack-to-trade scheme" that netted about $93 million for trading corporate information stolen from US. computer networks. Roman Seleznev, son of a Russian lawmaker, was also released from prison in 2017 for a massive hacking scheme that targeted point-of-sales systems and resulted in $169 million in losses.

The Orioles activated outfielder Eloy Jiménez, left-hander Trevor Rogers and outfielder Austin Slater on Thursday after obtaining them in trades and recalled infielder Livan Soto from Triple-A Norfolk. Baltimore put All-Star infielder Jordan Westburg on the 10-day injured list and optioned outfielder Heston Kjerstad and left-hander Keegan Akin to Norfolk. Westburg broke his right hand when he was hit by a pitch in Wednesday's win over Toronto.

articles.summary: The Baltimore Orioles have designated outfielder Cristian Pache for assignment, less than a week after acquiring him from Philadelphia. The team also put All-Star infielder Jordan Westburg on the 10-day injured list due to a broken hand. The Orioles have activated Eloy Jiménez, Trevor Rogers, and Austin Slater after obtaining them in trades and recalling Livan Soto from Triple-A Norfolk.

articles.title: Lee Kiefer gets her 3rd Olympic gold as the US wins a team fencing event for the first time
articles.description: Lee Kiefer has become the first American fencer to win three Olympic gold medals as the U.S. got its first-ever team fencing gold in women's team foil at the Paris Olympics. The team of two-time individual gold medalist Kiefer, silver medalist Lauren Scruggs, Jacqueline Dubrovich and Maia Weintraub held on for a 45-39 win over Italy in the gold-medal bout. Scruggs faced a late rally from Italy's Arianna Errigo, who cut an eight-point U.S. lead to three, but the 21-year-old took the next three points to close out the win and celebrated with a shout of delight.

articles.summary: Lee Kiefer, the first American fencer to win three Olympic gold medals, has achieved the first-ever team fencing gold in women's team foil at the Paris Olympics. The US won 45-39 over Italy, with Lauren Scruggs, Jacqueline Dubrovich and Maia Weintraub securing the win. Despite a late rally from Italy's Arianna Errigo, the team held on to their win.

articles.title: Salad kits are convenient. But are they more likely to be contaminated than regular lettuce?
articles.description: Pre-packaged salads can come with a risk of being exposed to certain bacteria. Here are some safety tips to follow.
articles.content:
Salad kits are convenient. But are they more likely to be contaminated than regular lettuce?

Storing salad kits and lettuce in general at the correct temperature, which is 40°F, can keep bacteria at ... [5867 symbols]
articles.summary: Salad kits and bagged salads are more likely to be contaminated than regular lettuce, but this is not the case. These prepackaged salads can come with a risk of exposure to certain bacteria and other potentially harmful microorganisms. These products have been recalled by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) several times over the past. Contamination can occur at various stages, starting with the growing process where leafy greens can be exposed to pathogens from contaminated water, soil or manure. However, unbagged lettuce, often perceived as fresher and more natural, can present a higher risk if proper washing and handling practices are not followed. Food safety tips can include washing all types of lettuce and choosing reputable suppliers. The number of food recalls and expiration dates can be followed.

articles.summary: The Los Angeles Chargers' star quarterback, Justin Herbert, will be sidelined for weeks due to a foot injury that could impact the start of the 2024 regular season. Herbert injured the plantar fascia on his right foot during a practice and requires two weeks in a walking boot and is expected to gradually return to regular action in the coming weeks. The team hopes Herbert can be ready for the start-of-the-season opener on Sept. 8, when the Chargers face their divisional rivals, the Las Vegas Raiders. This injury could potentially impact the team's offensive prowess, as it lost wide receiver Mike Williams to the New York Jets and traded Keenan Allen to the Chicago Bears. If Herbert is not ready to start, Easton Stick is likely to take over the starting duties.

articles.title: Former Dublin Prison Guard Charged With New Crimes
articles.description: If convicted, Daryl "Dirty Dick" Smith could face life in prison for 15 counts of sexual abuse.
articles.content: DUBLIN, CA — A grand jury issued a 15-count indictment against former FCI Dublin correctional officer Daryl Smith, replacing a 12-count indictment issued against Smith in April 2023. The new indictmen... [1994 symbols]

keywords.name: former FCI Dublin correctional officer Daryl Smith

articles.summary: A grand jury has issued a 15-count indictment against former FCI Dublin correctional officer Daryl Smith, replacing a 12-count original indictment issued in April 2023. The new indictment adds two new counts of sexual abuse from two new victims and adds a civil rights violation from aggravated sexual abuse Smith allegedly committed against one of the female inmates. If convicted, Smith could face 15 years in prison, which would last for the rest of his life. The indictment alleges that Smith began abusing inmates under his authority as early as August 2016, and until May 2021. Many, including former Warden Ray Garcia, have pleaded guilty to various counts of sex crimes. In response to the scandal, President Biden signed the Federal Prison Oversight Act, which mandates routine inspections of all federal prisons and established a new Ombudsman to investigate the health, safety and welfare of inmates and staff.

articles.summary: High school history teacher Marc Fogel, who was arrested in Russia in 2021 for possessing medical marijuana prescribed to him for chronic pain, was sentenced to 14 years in a penal colony for drug trafficking at the height of the Ukraine war. Despite efforts from lawmakers and his family, the State Department has not included Fogel in a prisoner swap for WNBA player Brittney Griner. The prisoner swap involved seven countries and involved the largest one in post-Soviet history. Fogel's 95-year-old mother, Malphine Fogel has filed a lawsuit against Secretary of State Antony Blinken for failing to designate her son as “wrongfully detained”

articles.content: “I’ve been clear with Steward, they need to stay open for 120 days. We need to have a smooth transition. Steward made the call to close those two hospitals,” Healey told reporters. “We have been hard ... [2666 symbols]
articles.summary: Massachusetts Governor, Mary Healey, has stated that Steward Health Care must give 120-day notice before closing hospitals in order to ensure a smooth transition of ownership away from Steward. This comes after the company announced it would close two hospitals. Healey also suggested that lenders should break the leases of these hospitals, which Steward owes after selling their physical properties to another company. The state has agreed to provide about $30 million to support the operations of six hospitals Steward is trying to turn over to new owners. A Senate committee has approved an investigation into Steward's bankruptcy and to subpoena CEO Ralph de la Torre.

The company announced its bankruptcy May 6 and announced it plans to sell off the 30 hospitals it operates across the country. articles.summary: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) has introduced the No Kings Act in response to President Joe Biden's plans to reform the U.S. Supreme Court. The bill, which has over two dozen Democratic cosponsors, comes after Biden called on lawmakers to ratify a constitutional amendment limiting presidential immunity, establish term limits and an enforceable ethics code for the court’s nine justices. The proposal is seen as a warning to the court and an effort to rally their voting base ahead of the presidential election. Critics, including liberal Justice Sonia Sotomayor, have criticized the decision, which was quoted by Biden himself.

articles.title: Comprehensive ESG Strategy Drives Progress on Key Issues and Positions American Airlines for Long-Term Success

articles.content: Sustainability at American includes protecting the safety of our team members and customers, attracting and developing the talent we need, providing our customers with a world-class travel experience ... [7161 symbols]
articles.summary: Sustainability at American Airlines is a key strategy for the company, which includes protecting the safety of its team members and customers, providing a world-class travel experience, and positioning American to compete in a low-carbon economy. The airline has developed a comprehensive approach to environmental, social and governance issues, including climate-related risks and opportunities. The company conducts sustainability-focused materiality assessment processes and identifies responsible sourcing as a key topic of growing importance. American Airlines also serves as part of the Dow Jones Sustainability World Index (DJSI World) and is one of only two passenger airlines to be included in this index. The CEO, who leads the company's operations, results and financial performance, has ultimate responsibility for its climate strategy.

articles.summary: Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker is being considered as a possible running mate for Vice President and anticipated Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris. A source tells CNN that Pritzer has had two Zoom interviews with Harris aides and has submitted thousands of pages of documents to the vetting process. The second interview included former Biden White House counsel Dana Remus, who is helping run the process. Pritzkers is one of approximately a dozen individuals being vetted as a potential running mate to Harris. The Democratic vice-presidential nominee is expected to be announced by next week.

articles.summary: A construction worker has been rescued from a trench collapse in San Mateo, California, which left him in a critical condition. Veronica Macias reports that the worker was rescued following the collapse. The collapse has been blamed for causing injuries to the construction worker and his family.

articles.title: Deaths of 2 toddler twins found unresponsive in van on I-95 back in February ruled a homicide
articles.description: Authorities said there are pending murder charges against the mother of 2 toddler twins found dead in a van on I-95.
articles.content: MIAMI - Authorities said Thursday that the mother of two twins who were found unresponsive in a silver van on the northbound Interstate 95 ramp to the Turnpike Extension at the Golden Glades interchan... [2767 symbols]
articles.summary: The deaths of two toddler twins, Milson Cadet and Milenjhit Gabriella Napoleon Cadet, who were found unresponsive in a silver van on the northbound Interstate 95 ramp to the Turnpike Extension at the Golden Glades interchange in February have been ruled a homicide. The children were identified as 3-year-old fraternal twins, a boy and a girl. Their mother, Shirlene Alcime, was rushed to HCA Florida Aventura Hospital in critical condition at the time. Police received multiple calls about a child being unresponsive and another from a passerby about 2 a.m. The driver of the vehicle, who was driving the vehicle where the children were located, then fell over the railing to the on-ramp onto the railroad tracks.
